 At Colorado State University in Fort Collins, public safety experts and the president's cabinet support a gun ban. 
 
 Before the decision is made, however, the school wants to hear what students think. 
 
 Wednesday night, the student governing body voted 21-3 in support of keeping CSU a conceal-and-carry campus. Five student senators were absent or did not vote. 
 
 The student leaders will now submit their resolution to the CSU president for consideration. 
 
 Author of the bill, CSU Junior Cooper Anderson said, "We wrote this bill because we felt that a student should have the right to self defense on campus. We don't believe that crime stops at a campus' borders." 
 
 CSU spokesperson Brad Bohlander says the Public Safety Team and the president's cabinet are united against the issue. 
 
 "More availability and more access to weapons on a highly populated college campus can potentially lead to more negative incidents," Bohlander told 9NEWS. 
 
 Besides Utah, where universities aren't allowed to ban guns, CSU is one of only a handful of universities across the country allowing concealed weapons. 
 
 CSU has never had a violent gun incident on campus. 
 
 "I think whenever you create a gun-free zone, you have an opportunity for criminals to act with impunity," Larimer County Sheriff Jim Alderden said. 
 
 Some students think CSU should be a gun-free zone. 
 
 "I don't think we should be allowed to have firearms on campus. I think it's dangerous and not needed. I think people shouldn't have guns just in general. If you have guns, that just causes more violence," Freshman Victoria Arias said.

 “Have you considered that having a gun on campus creates the opportunity for a violent incident, where one wouldn't be available normally?”
 
 I want to answer the question again by first noting I have heard a variant of this question many times before.
 
 It was asked when we decided to allow airline pilots to carry firearms again: “Have you considered having a gun (on a plane) increases the opportunity for a violent incident, where one wouldn’t be available normally?” 
 
 The argument advanced against this policy was that the same pilot we trust with our lives—to land a plane safely, to not commit suicide with it by crashing it into a building—cannot be trusted with a gun. If he had a gun then he might go off and shoot someone—or so the argument went. We have trusted pilots to carry for years now, and this prophecy of blood spilled in the skies has not been fulfilled. 
 
 Now the argument can be made that pilots go through a rigorous training program and this somehow makes them different than ordinary citizen CCW permit holders….
 
 Consider the case of Florida, then. Florida was mocked when it decided to revamp its CCW permit law and make it far easier to lawfully carry concealed. Opponents of concealed carry started calling Florida the “gunshine state.” They said we could not trust the citizens to carry firearms, and they made dire predictions of how traffic accidents would now become shootouts. The same argument was raised there: “Have you considered having a gun (in someone’s purse or car) increases the opportunity for a violent incident, where one wouldn’t be available normally?” 
 
 Florida chose to trust its citizens to carry concealed, and where is the increase in violence from the permit holders?
 
 The Commonwealth of Virginia decided some fifteen years ago to relax its CCW permit law and allow more people to carry concealed—at that time without any training requirement whatsoever. The same argument was made against that law: “Have you considered having a gun (in someone’s pocket/purse/car) increases the opportunity for a violent incident, where one wouldn’t be available normally?” 
 
 Virginia trusted its citizens to carry concealed, and where is the increase in violence by CCW permit holders?
 
 In addition, Virginia has for years trusted CCW permit holders to have a firearm while on a secondary school campus—without a single incident of violence. 
 
 Many states have for years trusted CCW permit holders. Has anyone ever cited a mass shooting—from any location—which was caused by a CCW permit holder? 
 
 Now turn to students and faculty/staff members who have CCW permits. Yes, I have considered the question raised above. But I believe that question is based upon fear without foundation—while my position is based upon trust. 
 
 We trust these students/faculty members to make calculations which help NASA guide a spacecraft to Mars. We trust them to enter and make use of nuclear reactor facilities. We trust them to handle and learn about deadly infectious diseases. We trust them to operate on people in teaching hospitals. 
 
 But we can’t trust them to carry concealed on campus? 
 
 Bear in mind the State which issues them a CCW permit already trusts them to carry concealed when they go grocery shopping at Food Lion, and when they buy a cheeseburger at the local McDonalds. That trust has not been misplaced. (the same applies to non-school personnel—like the CCW permit holding HVAC repair man who comes to work on a campus building and who is already trusted to carry concealed to and from other job sites.) 
 
 And so the real question becomes: For those who already have a CCW permit, is there any evidence to suggest they suddenly decompensate and become untrustworthy the moment they set foot on campus, only to become rehabilitated and able to safely carry concealed again when they leave and go home to their off campus apartments or to the video store? 
 
 Let’s be honest here. Isn’t a ban on firearms on campus based upon a belief that no one can be trusted at anytime, anywhere, for any reason to carry concealed—despite the overwhelming lack of evidence to support that belief? Isn’t support for a campus ban based upon the logic that if you can’t ban concealed carry altogether then a partial, location based ban is better than having no ban at all—sort of a fear monger’s consolation prize, if you will? 
 
 Be honest, now. If you support a campus ban, then don’t you also believe we should ban concealed carry altogether? Or do you support concealed carry—just not on campus? If so, then how do you credibly argue that students/faculty/staff members can be trusted to carry concealed while shopping on aisle 7 for ice cream—but they cannot be trusted to carry concealed while learning about geology or history?
